div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Praedestinatio vero
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, c. 1
etc. This is distinction 40 in which, after the Master determined about the knowledge and foreknowledge of God in general, now he begins to determine about a certain specific part of it. And it is divided into two parts because in the first place he treats predestination, in the second reprobation. The second part begins at
cumque praedestinatio
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, c. 2
.

The first part is divided into two because in the first place he considers the definitional ratio of predestination, in the second place about its enduring effect and its fixed duration. The second part begins at
praedestinatorum nullus videtur
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, c. 1
.

The second principal part is also divided into two parts because in the first place the Master posits the effect of positive reprobation, in the second place its privative effect. The second begins at
et sicut praedestinatio
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, c. 2
. And these things suffice for the division of the present distinction, about which it is asked:

Whether God is able to reveal to someone their certain damnation who is predestined or eternally existing in charity; whether to one existing in charity or predestined eternally God is able to reveal their damnation with certainty?

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p:
That not because no one is predestined eternally, therefore. The antecedent is proved both because someone is able to begin to be predestined, and because it follows that the number of predestined would not be able to be increased, and again because it follows that someone would be written in the book of life in an irremovable way. The falsity of the consequent is clear through
Psalm 64 ,
Let them be removed from the book of the living
Psalmus 68:29 . The consequence is clear because every eternal thing is unchangeable.

In the second principal place, it is repugnant that someone predestined be damned in an ultimate way, therefore. The antecedent is proved because it would follow that someone would be predestined and not predestined. Again in the second place because the God being would seem changed when he wished to save them and does not save them. Again in the third place because it follows that the Sacred Scriptures will be false which say that the predestined will be saved. This is confirmed through
Augustine, VIII De civitate Dei, chapter 51 , when he says,
for whom he foreknew he predestined to be like the image of his Son
Romanos 8:29
among these people non are able to perish
Augustinus, De civitate Dei, XVIII, 51, 2.
.

In the third principal place, such a revelation is not able to made to someone predestined or existing in charity, therefore. The antecedent is proved because then there eternal damnation
would occur necessarily; again because would give to himself and reason and occasion for despairing; and again because then one seeing God clearly as the highest good would be in pain or would be able to be in pain.

In opposition, it is argued because someone predestined is able to be damned, therefore their damnation is able to be revealed and shown clearly to them. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear through the
Master, in distinction 40 of the first book
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, xxx
.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: for everything predestined and graciously elected by God God prepared a multitudinous effect of grace and glory. This is clear through
Apostle, in Ephesians chapter one ,
he predestined into adoption of sons, according to the purpose of his will in praise of the glory of his grace
Ephesios 1:5-6 . Again, through
Augustine, in Predestination, chapter 12 ,
predestination is the preparation of grace
Augustinus, De Praedestinatione Sanctorum c. 12, xxx
. Again, this is confirmed because divine predestination is the cause of predestined salvation, therefore the cause of those things which are required for reaching this end. But predestination is also preparation or eternal volition, such that the predestined in time is justified, preserved, obeys, believes, preserves, and this is most especially true in the case of adults.

First corollary: just as it is impossible that God now in the first place determines that something is future, so it is impossible that God begins to predestine. This is clear because he predestines eternally. This is confirmed because, if he were to begin etc, then it would follows that a was before this instance, and consequently in this instant it was future, that is in some preceding instant.

Second corollary: though God is able to foreknow more future things than he foreknows to be future, nevertheless he is not able to know more future things than he knows that he knows, and properly he is not able to increase the number of known things, foreknown things, or predestined things. The first is clear having supposed that the number of future things is certain and finite because he is able to wish that there is some future thing beyond any foreknown future thing and he is able to know that this future is. The second part is proved because God is the comprehensive actual knowledge of all things, therefore it is not possible that there are more things to know. The third part is proved because, if this were the case, the following copulative would be able to be verified at the same time, here the number of people to be saved contains more unities than before and before did not contain fewer, which is false. The consequence is clear because this is properly to increase the number, therefore it is clear that, just as the number of knowable things is not able to increase, so the number of the elect is not able to be intensified.

Third corollary: the book of life is infallible and irremovable writing. This is clear from
Daniel 12 ,
my people will be saved, all who have been written in the book of live
Danielis 12:1 . Again,
Isaiah ,
all who are written in life in Jerusalem will be called holy
Isaias 4:3 .

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
Second conclusion: though every reprobate is able to saved in the end, nevertheless not every one predestined is able in the end to be damned or assigned to eternal punishment. The first part is clear because in the divided sense it should be conceded according to the Master. This is confirmed because God contingently condemns the reprobate, therefore it is possible that these people are not condemned or were not condemned. The second part is proved because Christ is predestined, and nevertheless it is not possible that he is damned or assigned to eternal punishment, therefore. The antecedent is proved through the per
Apostle ,
the Son of God is predestined in virtue
Romans 1:4 . From this is clear that the saying of
Hugh
were restricted to created supposites, it would not have truth, where he says that
anyone who is blessed is able to not have been elected
XXX . For it is the case that Christ is elected, just as the predestined are, according to
that Song ,
elected from thousands
Canticos 5:10
which according to the
Gloss XXX
is understood to be about Christ.

First corollary: what God now wishes God is able to never wish or never have wished without there being any intrinsic change within him. This is clear because what is now electively predestined he is able to never have predestined.

Second corollary: words of diverse times said about God do not indicate a time measuring the act of God, but they signify the indistinct presence of eternity to the entire flow of time. This is clear because otherwise in the divine elective or predestining or condemning act there will be a pastness and a futureness, which is false.
Third corollary: that it is true that there is some predestined person whom God is not able to have predestined. This is clear about the supposite of Christ.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
Third conclusion: just as predestination is the election of the good to the happiness of perpetual glory, so predestination is the the condemning of the bad to the calamity of perpetual misery. The first is clear from itself a and through the
Master XXX . The second is clear through
Augustine, XXII or XXI De Civitate, chapter 4 , where he says that,
some in this life are predestined to go into eternal fire with the devil
Augustinus, De Civitate Dei XXI, 24, 1
. Again, on that word of John 17
none of them perished except the son of perdition
,
some of perdictions, says
Augustine
is the traitor of Christ predestined to perdition
Tract Io. 107.7
. Again,
Anselm ,
there is not only predestination of the good, but it also able to be said of the bad
Anselmus, De concordia, II, 2
. Again,
Augustine, in the Enchiridion, chapter 80 , says
God justly predestined some to punishment and other benevolently to grace
Augustinus, Enchiridion I, 26, 100
.

First corollary: though someone predestined is able to see in the word that he will damned in the end, nevertheless if it is revealed to him, then he will be damned contingently and not otherwise. The first is clear because, from the conclusion, when taking predestined loosely, someone will predestined will be damned.
In the second place, this part is proved in the divided sense because one predestined to glory is able be damned since their being saved is contingent. But that this would be able to be revealed is clear because it is not any more repugnant that the penalty be revealed to the predestined than the guilt. But de facto Christ revealed to Judas and Peter their guilt, therefore it was possible to reveal to Judas his penalty, and consequently his eternal damnation. But it would be able to be said that this is not similar because damnation is not repugnant to predestination, though it is repugnant to an effectu of damnation, namely of grace. But the infernal punishment is repugnant on account of its property, not only to the effect of predestination, but also to predestination itself because the following are incompatible, Socrates is predestined and Socrates will be eternally tormented. Therefore perhaps it would be said that it does not follow, God is able to reveal guilt, therefore he is able to reveal punishment. But against this it is argued that final perseverance in mortal sin de directo is repugnant to predestination, and nevertheless God revealed it to the Jews, namely saying,
you will die in your sins
John 8:24 ,
Iohannis VIII . Again,
John 6 ,
one of you is the devil
John 6:71 . Again,
it would be better for him, if he had not been born
Matthaeus 26:25 , etc. This is confirmed, the final desertion of God is to not want mercy or not wish for mercy. But to depart finally in guilt is the greatest part of damnation, but this is something God can reveal, as is clear through the preceding texts. The second part of the corollary is proved because for God to say or reveal something evident outside himself does not necessitate the future occurrence of something, any more than his saying something within himself that is immeasurably evident and certain, but this saying within himself does not necessitate, as is clear through the Master, therefore. The major premise is known, and the minor is in
distinction 38
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 38, xxx
.

Second corollary: God is not only able to reveal damnation to someone conditionally, but he is also able to reveal this to the one to be damned absolutely categorically. This is clear through the
first corollary

Third corollary: just as with the evidence of something revealed stands the contingency of the same thing, so the evidence of this revelation is able to be had without pain or sadness, or it is the case that one sees their own damnation and to have no displeasure about this. The first is clear because with the blessed's clear vision of future damnation it stands that this occurs contingently and that it is possible to never occur. The second part is clear because the one to whom such a revelation occurs would also see that it would be able not to occur, or at least he out to believe this, and thus would be able to hope for the grace of God and would not be obligated to despair. From this it is clear that, if such a person will with certainty be damned, though God would concur to the entity for the act of believing, nevertheless he would not concur to such believing effectively though perhaps he would improperly and objectively. From what has been said
the response to the question is clear because, though God is not able to make the predestined certain about his damnation in the word nevertheless it is possible that he see his own damnation clear and certainly in the word. The first part because then God would make him believe with certainty that he is damned, and thus God would be able to force him to sin, which is false. Second part is proved because he is able to him the dignity of eternal life and the appropriate culpability of punishment, therefore etc.

div.head: Objections and Responses
div.p:
Against the first conclusion, it is argued through
Blessed Augustine
XXX
on the passage from
John 14 ,
I go to prepare a place for you
, where he says they are not predestined in the predestining, therefore it follows that this preparation of grace and glory is able to occur from time and not only eternally, which is against what the conclusion says.

In the second place against the first corollary, some one is not predestined and is able to be predestined, therefore it is possible to begin to be predestined. Similarly, it would be able to be argued thus, that something is not future and is able to be future, therefore it is able to begin to be future.

In the third place against the second corollary, if God were able to know or foreknow more future things, then it also follows that he would be able to know or foreforknow fewer things, and thus it follows that would foreknow future things merely contingently and not necessarily, the opposite of which
Alphonsus, in distinction 38
Alphsonsu Vargas, Sent. I, d. 39, xxx
, tries to prove, where he argues thus, the not future is not future by less necessity than the past is the past, but it is necessary that the past is the past, therefore. The major is clear because there is not a greater repugnance here that there, since to each the same thing is predicated about its very self. And the minor is known. Item,
Augustine, II Contra Faustum, response 14 , says,
both future things are not able to become and past things are able to not have been
Augustinus, Contra Faustum II, resp. 14, xxx
.

In the fourth place
against the third conclusion
, is the
Psalm
let them be removed from the book of the living
. And again,
Exodus 23 ,
forgive them this sin or remove me from the book of life
.

Against the second conclusion, if one predestined were able to be damned and sin at the end, and similarly he was foreknown to be saved, it follows that the create will is able to be the cause of his own predestination. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because nothing is able to be the cause of this kind of variation except a created will.

Again, if this were so, no one would be able to be certain about their salvation through any revelation. The consequent is false, as is clear through what has been said above. In another way this is clear because then there would be no prophecy because according to
Cassiodorus ,
prophecy is a divine inspiration or revelation announcing the occurrence of things with immoveable truth
Cassiodorus, Expositio Psalmorum Prol. (PL 70:12)
. For if it were able to occur otherwise that it was prophesied, then it would not announce such a truth immovably.

In the third place against
the first corollary, the will of God is eternal and immutable, therefore nothing that he wills are things that he is able to not will. The consequence holds because, if God wishes a will be and then something else is able to be done by God which will not be a, it follows that something else done by God is able to frustrate the will of God.

In the fourth place, if he were able not to will what he wills, it follows from a similar reason that he would be able to make it that Abraham had not been, that a virgin had not given birth, that Christ had not redeemed the human race. The consequent is false because God lacks this alone, namely that he makes the past not past, according to
Anselm
XXX .

Against the third conclusion, it is argued through
Lombard, in distinction 40 , where he says that
predestination is only of the good
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, c. 1
, therefore it is not said respect to the bad or to what is foreknown.

In the second place against the first part of the first corollary, God is able absolutely to reveal to the foreknown who is existing in grace his final damnation, therefore he is also able to reveal electively to the predestined his damnation. The consequence holds because revelation is more repugnant to predestination as in this case than to the departure of grace

In the third place, either this revelation is licitly able to be asked for or not. If it is, then it follows that something would be able to know by this person which is against the will of God. If not, then it follows that God will be the cause of one's own desperation and sin.

In the fourth place, it follows that God would be able to deceive someone. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because, if God revealed to someone their damnation or some future truth, he will cause assent in them and belief about that thing, and nevertheless the opposite would be able to occur, from which fact it follows that this person is deceived and deceived by none other than God who is revealing and causing the assent, therefore.

To the first, it is said that predestination is taken in two ways. In one mode inasmuch as it is in itself and eternal preparation. In the second mode inasmuch as it is an effect and operation of this preparation, and thus Augustine speaks in the first mode and not the second.
To the second, the consequence is clear.

To the third, the consequent and the consequence are conceded. And to the proof, the major is denied if it is understood from about the thing of what is said because the past necessarily is past by the necessity of the consequence, and this is not as much as the other.
In the second place, it is said that, if this proposition is about the thing said, then it is still denied because then the following would be valid, just as this is necessary the past is past, so is this, the future is future, and this is false because the latter is absolutely contingent. And when it is proved, because it is not more repugnant etc., it is said that it is argued from many causes of truth to one, therefore the consequence is not valid. For this proposition the future is not future is able to have two causes of truth, one is the future is and is not future, and this is false. The other causes is the future is not and something is not future, and it is possible that this.

To Augustine, it is said that he speaks there and in similar places in the composite sense not in the divided sense. Whence he wishes to say that, just it is impossible that the past was not, so it is impossible that God wishes the future and it does not come to be.

To the argument from the
Psalm ,
let them be removed from the book of the living
Psalmus 68:29 , that is, those written in the book were never shown because those written in the book were seen in this life.

To the other, though this Moyses asked for this, nevertheless it does not follows that this was possible because even according to the
Philosopher ,
though there is a will for what is impossible, nevertheless one does not wish this absolutely
Aristotle, N. Ethics III, xxx
.

To the first against the second conclusion, it is said in the first place that when taking predestination for foreknowledge and preparation of a future benefit, in this case the consequent and the consequence are denied. But if predestination were taken for
and effect of predestination, then thus the consequent and the consequence are conceded because the created will is able to merit some effect of predestination and condemnation, and the same distinction in the virtue has been posited above.
To the second, the consequence is denied because, though he would be able to create and show this or another future, nevertheless he is not able to effectively produce certainty about it.

In the second place, it is said for the matter of the argument that this person will be made certain through this revelation, such that this certitude of adhesion excludes all doubt, nevertheless this person will not be certain with the certitude of demonstration or necessity. And when it is said that, then prophecy would not proclaim with the truth of an immoveable future, here it is said that, if immoveable is taken for that which in now way is able to be moved, then the consequent. But it is taken for that which will not be moved, then the consequences is denied, and this is how Cassiodorus speaks. Nevertheless note that some prophecy is according to foreknowledge, some according to communication which is not always filled according to the sound of the words. See
Clienton
XXX .

To the third, the consequence is denied because the volition of God with respect to future contingents is the kind of relation which is able to become a non-relation with any change being made in God, but only through a change in something else, just as column is able to become both right and left.

To the fourth, Clienton would say that it is possible through the divine power that Abraham and other past things were not because for God nothing is past,
see his arguments
. But the consequence would be able to be denied because this is not similar to the fact that the truth of something depends on something future.

To the first against the third conclusion, in the first place it is said that one should give more assent to Augustine than to the Master.
In the second place, it is able to be said there that the Master takes predestination strictly and properly, and thus this is not against the corollary Augustine because he takes predestination in the broad sense.

For which note that predestination sometimes is taken broadly and generally for ordering or preparation or fore-vision of some future, and this is how the term is understood by
Augustine, in Contra Pelagium, book 2, chapter 9
Augustinus, Contra Pelagium II, c. 9, xxx
.

In a second mode predestination is taken specifically for the pre-ordering of the divine will or foreknowledge or fore-vision in the arrangement of rational creatures or angels, and this is how the word is taken by Augustine where it was alleged above. Again in chapter 8
God justly predestined some to punishment and some benevolently to grace
Augustinus, Enchridion I, 26, 100, xxx
. Again,
Isidore, in book 2, chapter 6 ,
predestination is two-sided, namely of the elect to rest and of condemned to death
Isidorus, XXX, II, c. 6, xxx
.

In a third mode predestination is taken properly for the preordination of the good with respect to a rational creature, and predestination so described is the eternal preparation by the divine will for final grace in life and for perennial glory in heaven. This is clear through
Augustine in Praedestinatione sanctorum, chapter 12 , where he says,
predestination is the preparation of glory and ought to be understood about the final grace because many have grace who fall from it in the end
Augustinus, Praedestinatio Sanctorum c. 12, xxx
.

From which it is clear that not every grace gratifying is an effect of divine predestination when taking predestination in the first and second modes. This is clear because every thing precedes from the divine will in an eternally preordained way that it gives itself, etc.

It should be noted in the above that revelation sometimes it is taken only for a showing of some future thing, and this is the way it is spoken here. And this kind of revelation sometimes comes through corporal vision, but sometimes through a spiritual revelation, just as was the case in the vision of Pauli in rapture. Again, it should be known that to reveal something properly is to lead a created intellect to assent to something true about the future which this intellect does not itself assert. From which it is clear that no creature is able to reveal something to another except that which has been
revealed to the same person. This is clear because know creature is able to know the future unless God revealed it to them.

To the second, the consequence is denied when taking the consequent in the composite sense. The reason is because damnation is not as formally repugnant to grace as to predestination on account of permanence of miser and glory which are incompatible.

To the third, it is said thus this is so because, though God wishes that this person is damned, nevertheless he is able to never have wished this and not wish that he wishes this. In the second place, it is said that this person out to believe firmly that on account of this revelation God does not oblige this person to wish their own damnation. In the third place, it is said that no on every sees their damnation so clearly that they do not see that God makes the opposite way possible, and nevertheless they are able licitly to believe that they will be damned in the end.

To the last, the consequence is denied. In the second place, it would be possible to be said that it is impossible that God causes every assent in that one with respect to what is revealed and that the opposite occurs while this revelation exists. In the third place, it is said that God would be able to cause some assent with respect to something revealed which while the assent remains the one having it is able to cause another assent regarding the same thing on account of which they would be deceived, and such deception would not be from God and not on account of God.
To the arguments in the opposition, it is clear what should be said from what has been said above, etc. The text follows.

div.head: Conclusiones
div.p:
Praedestinatio vero
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 40, c. xxx.
. The first conclusion of this distinction 40: predestination is preparation of grace for achieving salvation. Whence there is double effect of predestination, a temporal one in this life, namely the infusion of grace another in eternal heavenly life, namely the collection of glory.

The second conclusion: when someone is said to be predestined, it is true that they are not able to be damned, if taken in the conjoined sense. But if taken in the divided sense, then it is false because the predestined is able not to be predestined, and thus to be damned.

Third conclusion: that just as God was able from eternity to not predestine someone, so it is conceded by some that God is now also able not to have predestined this person, therefore this person is able not to have been predestined nor now be predestined. But if they had not been predestined and were not now predestined, then consequently they are also now able not to be predestined. And it similarly able to be said about the foreknowledge and the foreknown. Nevertheless in the actions of creatures this is not conceded because what has been done or said by a creature is impossible not to have been done or said when relating to the possibility or impossibility of the existing thing to nature. But when it is done from the foreknowledge or predestination of God, possibility and impossibility is related to the punishment of God, which is always the same and always was the same.

Fourth conclusion: condemnation is the foreknowledge of iniquity of some people and the preparation of damnation for those same people, nevertheless he does so because he foreknows the iniquity but he does not prepare it, however he foreknows and prepares an eternal penalty

Fifth conclusion: that just as the effect of predestination is the operation of grace, so the effect of eternal condemnation is in some way or seems to be stubbornness, nevertheless God does not cause someone to be stubborn by imparting or by sending malice, but rather by not imparting grace. And these things suffice.
